questiontext.text:
Example

Find the Maclaurin expansion of \(e^x\ln(1+x)\).

Here, instead of finding the derivatives of \(f(x)=e^x\ln(1+x)\), we can more simply multiply together the Maclaurin expansions for \(e^x\) and \(\ln (1+x)\) which  we already know:

\[e^x=1+x+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}+\cdots\qquad \text{all}\ x\]

and

\[ \ln(1+x)=x-\dfrac{x^2}{2}+\dfrac{x^3}{3}+\cdots\qquad -1<x\leq 1.\]

The resulting power series will only be convergent if \(-1<x \leq 1\) .

Multiplying:

\[\begin{aligned}e^x\ln(1+x)&=\left(1+x+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}+\cdots\right)\left(x-\dfrac{x^2}{2}+\dfrac{x^3}{3}+\cdots\right)\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\\&=x-\dfrac{x^2}{2}+\dfrac{x^3}{3}-\dfrac{x^4}{4}+\cdots\\&\quad +\ x^2-\dfrac{x^3}{2}+\dfrac{x^4}{3}+\cdots\\&\qquad \quad\  +\ \dfrac{x^3}{2}-\dfrac{x^4}{4}\cdots\\&\qquad \qquad\quad\quad  +\dfrac{x^4}{6}\cdots\\&=x+\dfrac{x^2}{2}+\dfrac{x^3}{3}+\dfrac{3x^5}{40}+\cdots\qquad -1<x\leq 1\end{aligned}\]

(You must take care not to miss relevant terms when carrying through the

multiplication.)
